content:
Hi @esteban616 !
I've just get it today in CoC ... and get a poor result (partially solved) in time ...

But now get quickly 100% in IDE :-).
Bellow my Python (with recursion) :

import sys
import math

def r(i):
 if i>=len(d):return -1
 print(i, d[i], file=sys.stderr, flush=True)
 a=int(d[i])
 if a<1:return i
 return max(i, r(i+a), r(i+1))

d=input()
print(d, file=sys.stderr, flush=True)
o=r(0)
print(o)

I just had your problem in a COC.
I misread the statement and thought that when there is a non-zero digit D you can access ALL the indexes between +1 and +D. (and not only +1 and +D)
My code passed all the tests except the last one, but it passed all the validators.
Another player had the same problem (i tested his published code). We were the only ones to reach more than 50%.
I think your problem is a nice COC (not too difficult).
But in your example you should use bigger number (at least 3). So it would be clear that there's a jump.
And maybe add a simpler test that would break in this case.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun little problem :) I only wonder why the hint says to perform BFS while any search method would work just as fine.

it's hard but achievable in 15 minutes, although I do not understand why one test is wrong...

"".join([str(random.randint(0,6)) for i in range(60)]) TEST
Input
513053611530366145504030225046154335205403336110400340622125
Output
50 

...but 50 (which I think, counting manually...) is a zero in the 40034 section, or the first 4 in it, (did I count that wrongly?) so doesn't that break the rules?

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This problem is fun and not that hard (I have encountered more difficult problems during clashes). The tests were perfect and the description was really clear too so I would love to see this challenge during clashes.

Here is my python solution:

d = list(map(int,input()))
n = len(d)

t = [0] * n
t[-1] = n - 1

for i in range(n-2,-1,-1):
    if d[i] == 0:
        t[i] = i
    else:
        t[i] = max(t[i + 1], i + d[i] < n and t[i + d[i]])

print(t[0])

I think people will see that it's the pathfinding problem and just quit. Especially in the Fastest mode.
It is a pretty nice puzzle, and I don't think it's extremely hard so I can't reject it.
But I did spend something like 9 minutes on it so I can't approve.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: This problem is fun and clearly described. Tests and validators are perfect. However, i think it is too hard to be fun for a clash because it will take too much time to solve when not familiar with pathfinding.
Nevertheless, this problem would make a fun and good easy puzzle for pathfinding learning

Here is my python code, took me 20 minutes to reach 100%

---
import sys
import math

max=0
index=0
digits = input()
tries=[(0,0)]
while True:
    if tries==[] :
        break
    if index == len(digits)-1 :
        break
    (index, jump) = tries.pop(0)
    index += jump
    if index >= len(digits) :
        continue
    if index > max:
        max = index
    jump = int(digits[index])       
    if jump>0: 
        tries.append((index, 1))
    if jump > 1 : 
        tries.append((index, jump))    
print(max)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I have seen much more difficult pathfinding problems that were accepted, such as moving the horse. This problem is simple and clean. I loved it.

PLEASE ATTEMPT MY CHALLENGE BEFORE REVIEWING OR READING COMMENTS THANK YOU

Hello reviewers, I have not yet seen a search problem on clash so I wanted to add one. Search can be difficult so I wanted to make a simple as possible BFS puzzle.

If reviewers feel this is too complicated I would understand.  BFS implementation can be difficult if you lack familiarity with the algorithm.

Please look over my tests and validations. I know that may be tedious, so if you are not willing, leave the approval for someone else. Additionally, if you think of other corner cases consider contributing them so that I may add the test.

Thank you for your interest and feedback.

Okay so I was able to solve it in time but that's because I'm familiar with BFS.

(The length check got me the first time though since I naively assumed you could never go beyond the last digit. Although the statement does imply it, it could be made a bit clearer I think)

Even though the solution is relatively simple, if you don't know BFS beforehand it's probably gonna be tough to solve it.

Also, perhaps I'm imagining it but this reminds me a lot of today's AOC xD
Andre, thank you for reviewing my contribution. Using the for each loop with the two possible paths is clever, I did not anticipate that technique.
Thank you for reviewing my contribution. I understand your reason to not approve. I am glad you enjoyed the question regardless.
Thank you for reviewing lopidav. I hope you had fun attempting the question!
This is an elegant solution very nice!
You are correct I am not trying to mislead. Do you think I should clarify? Maybe, hint: implement a search algorithm such as Depth First Search.

I updated the problem description in an effort to clarify your confusion on jumping on all the in between values. Please have a look.

I believe Test 2 (Need to jump) already covers the problem you are referencing.

If you were to share your code I could investigate your single failure. Because the range of possible outputs is relatively small, I believe you could incorrectly get the correct answer. I am not too concerned, I would rather have a false positive in the validator than any other incorrect variations.

An example could be :
302011111
With my code i take ALL the 3 values 020 so the largest index attainable would be 8 (thanks to the 2 that allows me to reach the ones).
But the real solution is 3 (because 2 is "jumped").
My solution output the right answer for the test 2 and its validator.
I hope it's a bit clearer.
I think that adding "such as" would be perfect :)
Done.
I've just recounted and the digit of index 50 is the second 0 40034 so no rule broken since you can reach by jumping from the previous 6.
Thank you for your reviews. I also love his solution I had not looked at the problem in this way.

:) my solution above doesn't work in all cases, so some work to do to fix it. Most likely that is as far as I'd have got in a CoC : sometimes I quite enjoy a more difficult one like this but I can see how it'd be frustrating if you were looking for 5-minute challenges. I'm therefore torn on whether this would work for a CoC so not accepting or rejecting it myself. If pressed I'd say go for it and then decide later to keep it depending on feedback once it was live

(edit: I see it is approved :D )

esteban616 : I just got this in a CoC and I did only get to my solution as posted here and I got 100% in the validation on submitting yet it was still failing the test for 
513053611530366145504030225046154335205403336110400340622125
...not sure if that was intentional but you might need to add another test or two to the validation after submission? :)
Oh, I had fun, yes

It may not be necessary to inform that the person must use BFS. Because the problem calls for only the highest index that is possible to reach. I believe it can be solved with DFS, a simple recursive function.

Yes, I originally wanted to make a shortest path problem. However, I believe that is too difficult for CoC. I think many participants will have a difficult enough time finding the last index without reconstructing and formatting the shortest path. I included that portion as a comment in my solution.

Consequently, and I agree, a search such as DFS should also solve this challenge.
In reflection, I think that behavior is inconsistent with the rest of the question. I think I will limit to the maximum index. Thank you for your feedback, I will make updates.
